summary: Trained lawyer and University lecturer by profession, Dr. Mbembe has a great interest in the promotion and protection of human rights. In this regard, he founded in 2001 Initiatives for Peace and Human Rights (iPeace), a regional NGO which is currently working in Burundi, DR Congo and Rwanda with the grassroots people and local authorities. Apart from the field of human rights in which he was called first by necessity then by passion, Mr. Mbembe has an outstanding politico-legal expertise on the African Great Lakes region that he has been scanning for over ten years. His excellent mastery of the region combined with his academic qualifications made him a first-choice consultant for renowned institutions and organizations, especially in the field of Peace-building, Human Rights, Good Governance, Rule of Law, Regional Integration and Foreign Investments.

profile_positions.description:
In this position, I coordinated the activities of the Great Lakes regional training program on international humanitarian law and human rights co-organised by le Comité pour le Concours Grands Lacs (CCGL) based in Geneva (Switzerland) and Initiatives for Peace and Human Rights (iPeace). This capacity-building project was mainly intended to empower undergraduate law students and teachers of universities located in Burundi, DR Congo and Rwanda with relevant and practical knowledge about national, regional, and international instruments which may be used to prevent or to punish violations of international humanitarian law and human rights that this region has been facing since the 1990s. Since 2013, 171 law students and lecturers from 22 universities have been trained. Specifically I was in charge of:
-	Coordinating program or project planning and implementation, including assessing needs, setting goals and objectives.
-	Participating in project budget planning, development, and fundraising.
-	Establishing project work plan and calendar or schedules; monitoring, reviewing, and evaluating progress.
-	Coordinating and attending meetings; establishing and maintaining internal and external contacts as necessary.
-	Providing advice to participants; serving as a liaison; acting as a resource person by performing research, analysing information, providing documentation, and preparing reports.
-	Monitoring record keeping and file maintenance for the program or project.
-	Supervising other 9 project staff; assigning tasks; setting priorities.
-	Preparing records of project activities; overseeing and ensuring the timely processing in and the delivery of required materials.
-	Verifying and analysing the accuracy of all data and information used or generated by project; resolving any discrepancies or problems.
-	Serving as liaison for department; coordinating activities and exchanges information.
profile_positions.title: Project Coordinator - Great Lakes Human Rights Regional Training Programme

profile_positions.company: Initiatives for Peace and Human Rights
profile_positions.description:
This emergency project funded by UNHCR through Plan International Rwanda intended to provide access to justice to about 70,000 Burundian refugees located in Mahama Camp, Bugesera and Nyanza reception centres, and Kigali city, especially to the survivors of Sexual and Gender Based Violence (SGBV) and Child Protection incidents (CP). The project was also tasked to support the late birth registration process of the children born to Burundian refugees.
In 4 months, my team and I received and handled 233 cases, including 33 SGBV cases, 26 CP cases, 5 common-law cases (robbery, alimony, etc.), and 169 birth registration cases. This represents an average of 58,2 cases per month and approximately 2 cases per calendar day.
profile_positions.title: Project Coordinator - Legal Services for Access to Justice for Burundian Refugees (LS4AJ)

profile_positions.description:
The University of Rwanda is the oldest and the world’s best-ranked university in Rwanda. As lecturer of law at this university, I have directly empowered with legal knowledge and legal research skills about 1,000 students in five years. In my teachings the regional integration approach is preponderant. Among others, I have taught the following:
-	Economic and Financial Law (the equivalent of Commercial Law in the American system): I have been teaching this course to undergraduate final year students since 2011. This year (2013) I have put more stress on the attraction and the management of Foreign Direct Investments in the East African Community. With students I explored the legislations of all EAC partner states and the EAC treaty and protocols. Research and discussions were held among others about the applicability of the NT and MFN principles vis-à-vis the EAC integration process. Compliance to GATT and GATS core principles and exceptions were also tackled.
-	Methods of Legal Research: Intended to provide 3rd year law student with knowledge and skills on how to find, explore and analyze legal documents to make a clear and concise report. This course prepares law students for the redaction of their final dissertation. I taught this course between 2007 and 2010. 
-	Introduction to Scientific Research: This course is intended to 1st year law students to get them used to legal terminology, to find out legal resources, to read and understand legal writings and documents. I taught this course in 2008, 2009 and 2010.
-	Law of contractual liability: Providing to useful knowledge on principles applicable in civil contracts and the consequences of their violations.
-	I have also taught Advocacy Techniques (2010), Techniques of Legal Drafting (2009 & 2010), Introduction to Private Law (2010 & 2011), and Law of transportation (2008). Supervised students assignments and dissertations in private law domain.
-	Carry out research in group or alone

profile_positions.company: Supreme Court of the Republic of Rwanda
profile_positions.description:
In Rwanda, so far a decision taken by the Supreme Court is binding to the lower courts when they face a similar issue. But the consistency of the system depends on how courts at various levels align their respective decisions not just with those rendered by the Supreme Court but also with those taken by any other hierarchically higher court. This alignment fosters harmony and coherence of justice decisions, which definitely strengthens the public confidence in the judiciary. In the framework of the UNDP-funded project "Research on Leading Jurisprudence from Civil Cases in Rwandan Courts", I am leading a team made of 4 legal experts and 1 social science researcher in order:
- To identify and assess legal issues arising from civil cases decided by Rwandan courts between 2010 and 2015
- To assess and discuss legal basis (statutes and regulations, jurisprudence and other leading authorities) for decision, provided in identified cases
- To identify, highlight and justify the selection of the leading jurisprudence and legal basis thereto.
- To provide supplementary legal information that can help judges to decide upon related cases and serve as legal reference for legal practitioners.
profile_positions.title: Lead Consultant - Research on Leading Cases Arising from Civil Cases in Rwandan Courts

profile_positions.description: As a practicing lawyer with the Kigali Bar Association (KBA), I help individuals and companies resolve legal disputes. In so doing I conduct research, write legal documents, argue a client's case before courts or negotiate settlement terms. My specialization area covers: Foreign Investment Law, Company Law, Economic and Financial Law, Contractual Liability, Human Rights, Torts, Agency, Fiduciary, Competition to name but a few. Through the affiliation of KBA to the East African Law Society (EALS), I am de jure member of the EALS which entitles me to practice in all EAC partner states (Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda and Tanzania).

profile_positions.description:
I did data collection and analysis of Rwanda laws relating to trade in services to determine their compliance with the EAC Common Market Protocol. This research was governed by a pre-determined questionnaire and research process outline. The Rwanda country information contributed to the construction of a regional index on free movement of
services for the EAC.
Specifically:
- I reviewed and analyzed Rwanda’s commercial laws concerning trade in services to determine their compliance with the "Freedom of Movement of Services in EAC" chapter of the EAC Common Market Scorecard.
- I participated in constructing the regional index and narrative report.
- I implemented a country-specific verification process on preliminary data collection results.
- I ensured submission of duly filled data collection forms by respondents and ministries of EAC, and compiled all information sources to ensure data traceability.
- I participated, when requested, in developing informational, promotional and media
material for the EAC Common Market Scorecard in relation to the freedom of
movement of services.
- I also produced any other reasonable output as agreed by the World Bank Group in the development of the EAC scorecard.
